ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Better Spanish skills in writing, listening, reading and speaking.
Lots of reading practice and a higher level understanding of basic spanish structures
I learned about pop culture, literature, and some important historical events in various spanish-speaking countries.
I learned how to apply basic grammar and sentence structures orally and written-wise. I also learned a lot about various Latin American cultures as well.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Very hands on, great for improving your Spanish.
Strength would be not having it every day and having half of the lessons be self directed to be reviewed during the next meeting time.
I think it will improve significantly once it can again take place in an in person classroom setting

Strengths were how engaging classes were, with a mix of short lectures, breakout rooms, skits, practice questions, etc. I liked having practice exercises as well so that I could make sure that I was practicing the new grammar I learned. I liked the SuperSite questions. We also received timely and great feedback on our assignments. The only weakness of the class was that we received a lot of handouts on Zoom, and I would have preferred the documents to be more organized - perhaps all the files could have been uploaded on Canvas so we could go back to them. I think having answer keys to all the practice questions would have been helpful, as well as more (low-stake) opportunities to speak and practice our grammar would have been helpful.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Online class with breakout rooms worked well and were a good replacement for the interactive language classroom environment.
speaking practice through breakout rooms felt really weird, but I don't really see a way of improving it so maybe integrate another form of conversational practice!
The breakout rooms worked really well to allow us to practice speaking Spanish amongst each other. The asynchronous lectures also helped a lot, especially to address Zoom fatigue.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you want to improve your Spanish.
Yes, need it for your language credit and I do feel more comfortable with my spanish after taking it
Yes! You really do strengthen your skills in Spanish and the class is genuinely really fun.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In person, non-recorded class, with a lot of breakout room activity.
Combination of asynchronous and synchronous classes. Asynchronous classes were self directed, but the material covered by individuals would be reviewed during synchronous classes.
conversations were practiced through individual breakout rooms and lots of other changes to meet with zoom/remote capabilities
course modules; (short, optional) online lectures on asynchronous days
